“Case Logics: Furnishing a Bureaucratic Implosion,” Kluge Center, Library of Congress, April 15, 2025; Disrupting Disruption Series, hosted by Alex Ketchum, McGill University, May 8, 2025

This talk — which emerged from Shannon’s tenure as a research chair at her embattled country’s national library during a time of destruction and disarray — focuses on the bureaus of bureaucracy. It examines the nature and value of bureaucracy in sustaining a democracy, as well as the apparatae that furnish it; the current administration’s fetishization and debasement of that democratic equipment; as well as strategies for "turning the tables" and imagining new administrative equipment for insubordination.

Normally I’d share my slides, but I’m claiming fair use of some news footage and poking fun at thin-skinned elites, so I’ll post some low-res screenshots instead. I’d be happy to share a link to the deck to folks who promise not to report me to the DOJ

Thinking with Tables https://wordsinspace.net/2025/03/13/thinking-with-tables/ Thu, 13 Mar 2025 05:26:32 +0000 Blog,conservation,furniture,Libraries I wrapped up my second month as the Kluge Chair of Modern Culture at the Library of Congress. Last month — as I gazed upon Chesapeake landscapes from the Amtrak train; puzzled over the variously (de-)fenestrated conditions of the Library’s Jefferson, Madison, and Adams buildings; imagined the Library’s collections as portals into historical and cultural […]

I wrapped up my second month as the Kluge Chair of Modern Culture at the Library of Congress. Last month — as I gazed upon Chesapeake landscapes from the Amtrak train; puzzled over the variously (de-)fenestrated conditions of the Library’s Jefferson, Madison, and Adams buildings; imagined the Library’s collections as portals into historical and cultural knowledge; and gazed upon the Capitol building, and imagined all the tumult erupting within, from the serenity of the Library’s Great Hall — I thought a lot about windows, both literal and metaphorical. This month, I seem to have turned my attention to tables.

Tables have been a persistent subject of fascination. Back in 2016 I wrote about filmmaker Zoe Belloff’s engagement with the early-2oth-century “time-motion studies” of scientific management researchers Frank and Lillian Gilbreth, who documented the choreography of various administrative tasks — folding papers, stuffing envelopes, filling boxes — at differently structured work stations. The following year I wrote a piece for e-flux about the communal tables that were so prevalent in Silicon Valley work spaces, and which created the “material conditions for compulsory community, coercive commitment, and competitive productivity.” In 2018, then, I wrote about the aesthetic and political significance of the various work surfaces at Brett Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing: the white male Senators’ elevated dais, which hovered over the female special assistant’s tiny desk and confronted Christine Blasey Ford’s testimonial table. And in my various information infrastructure classes over the years we’ve grappled with the tabula from Foucault’s The Order of Things — the material tables and spreadsheets on and in which we organize and classify objects and ideas.

In 2023 I wrote a piece about the kitchen tables and makeshift work surfaces (from ironing boards to bathroom counters) at which so many of us “tele-worked” throughout the pandemic. And last spring, to celebrate the imminent arrival of my friend Olga Touloumi’s book, Assembly by Design, we spoke at Princeton about the way tables in various shapes and sizes — intimate round tables, long banquet tables, picnic tables, ceremonial diases — organize us into different topologies, or geometric forms, that cultivate different means of engaging with one another and creating knowledge together.

These various projects illuminated my experiences in D.C. throughout the month of February. In the Rare Book and Special Collections Division I encountered numerous historical furniture guides and catalogs [below: Robert Conner, The Cabinet Maker’s Assistant (Faxon and Read, 1842; Ackermans’ Repository of the Arts; scroll right).

In the Manuscripts Division, I encountered lots of furniture catalogs and table-centric ephemera in the Charles & Ray Eames and Alexander Girard collections.

I was also grateful to be invited to for a back-stage tour of the Library’s Conservation Division, where I compared the medium-specific workstations of the book, photograph, and large-scale print conservators. Such a glorious range of mises en place! My generous host, Andrew Robb, Head of the Photograph Conservation Section, explained that much of the team’s work is structured and scored by space — by how much, and where, works will ultimately be stored; by where and how they’ll be “served” to patrons; and by the size of various workstations. The design of digitization work areas, he said, is also informed by time-motion studies; they calibrate the appropriate proportion of area dedicated to the “to do” and “finished” piles to maximize efficiency in the digitization workflow.

I contrasted these work spaces with the very different kinds of functional tables required in the viewing areas and back rooms of the Moving Image Research Center.

In these windowless spaces in the Madison Building, where skilled professionals — federal workers — are preserving the nation’s cultural heritage, I couldn’t help but think about the cruel, reckless destruction of public goods, and the devaluation of civil servants, taking place simultaneously outside, all over the city. The so-called Department of Government Efficiency was, and still is, ransacking government databases, clumsily scanning spreadsheets — “tables” of a different sort — by executing stupidly superficial CTRL+F searches for “DEI”-coded terms, then summarily terminating the programs and people associated with them. A former student and friend helped to build some of those digital systems as part of 18F; the entire team was laid off on March 1.

These oppositional sets of government workers — the information stewards at the Library and 18F, and the information saboteurs on the DOGE team — couldn’t represent more disparate approaches to reading, to honoring context, to enacting care. As former 18F-er Waldo Jaquith wrote, “18F works just how Musk and team pretend that they want government to work. But when his team found it, they destroyed it. 18F’s work is evidence that government works well, which undermines their message that it doesn’t.” So, DOGE invades their offices, commandeers their desks and tables, infiltrates their databases, and turns their carefully curated information and thoughtfully engineered systems against them.

While the tables are turning — tumultuously and tragically — across so many federal agencies, I was heartened to encounter several other institutional tables that embody much more convivial and contextual approaches to information management. A few weeks ago the Kluge Center organized for us fellows a guided tour of the newly renovated Folger Shakespeare Library, which sits right beside the LoC’s Adams Building. In the Folger’s new exhibition hall, designed by Studio Joseph and Bluecadet, we encounter a glass vault displaying all 82 of the Library’s copies of the 1623 First Folio. Before that vault stands an interactive table. The two speak to each other. As Bluecadet explains: “The Light Case acts as a sculptural data visualization, illuminating groupings of the folios, with each grouping explained by a key legend. The Touch Screen allows visitors to explore the folios through three distinct lenses — Detective, Storyteller/Historian, and Collector — offering unique insights into these rare artifacts.” The moving lights feel like illuminated manicules guiding our curiosity.

I’ve also been spending a lot of time at the relatively-recently-renovated MLK Library, the central facility of the D.C. Public Library system. Mecanoo refreshed D.C.’s only Mies building.

My friend Natalie Campbell, a curator at the MLK Library — who’s also been a phenomenal D.C. ambassador and social networker — helped to organize several displays on the building’s fourth floor, adjacent to their spectacular People’s Archive.

The same team responsible for the Folger exhibition hall — Studio Joseph and Bluecadet (along with Colloqate, Workhorse Collective, Kubik Maltbie, and Openbox) — also contributed to the MLK exhibitions, which focus on protest and change (including King’s local connections, the Poor People’s Campaign, and D.C.’s struggle for home rule — which is again threatened by the Trump regime), as well as the legacies of D.C. punk and go-go music.

My favorite component of the exhibition, though, is a table: the District Catalog, a “card catalog for community conversations,” where people can submit or answer a question about what matters to them. They can then file that question away into any of various subject headings in the catalog drawers suspended beneath the table.
Natalie told me that such an interactive exhibition necessitates continual upkeep, just as any social media platform requires content moderation to remove the egregiously inappropriate comments. The code and the hardware both require oversight: The cards need to be replenished. The pencils need to be sharpened. The drawers need to be tidied up.
And that’s only fitting: stewarding a collection, managing an information ecosystem, conserving an infrastructure, and sustaining a democracy all require investment and care and sturdy scaffolding and reliable maintenance and skilled workers empowered to provide those things.

Here, we see how a well-tended table, a humble-and-convivial infrastructure, can invite people — citizens and residents, locals and visitors — to share. A second grader visiting from Kentucky asks: “Why do people wish for peace but do nothing to help it happen?” A profound question. When an administration’s mission is to “delete entire agencies,” to put federal workers “in trauma,” to destroy departments from within, to withdraw from diplomatic engagements, to eliminate accountability and oversight, to alienate allies and emulate dictators, they certainly aren’t setting the table for peace. Perhaps we can learn from the conservators and curators, the furnituremakers and flatware designers, the philosophers and feminist critics (as well as the florists and bakers and barricade-makers) about how to set a table hospitable to democracy.

Windows on Washington https://wordsinspace.net/2025/02/03/windows-on-washington/ Mon, 03 Feb 2025 07:36:13 +0000 Blog,Libraries I’ve been spending a lot of time thinking about windows these past several weeks. I assume that’s in part because, after 12 years without a research leave, I finally have a bit of mental space — a cognitive window, if you’ll pardon the metaphor — that allows for the contemplation of such things. I’m tremendously […]

I’ve been spending a lot of time thinking about windows these past several weeks. I assume that’s in part because, after 12 years without a research leave, I finally have a bit of mental space — a cognitive window, if you’ll pardon the metaphor — that allows for the contemplation of such things. I’m tremendously grateful to have been nominated to serve as the 2025 Kluge Chair in Modern Culture at the LoC, which grants me some time to return to research I had to set aside years ago in order to attend to various administrative and family responsibilities.

I planned to spend several nights each week in DC, but when my AirBnb failed to live up to its description — the cold-water basement flat, where I had to keep the few, tiny egress windows shrouded to avert the eyes of passing pedestrians, was quite unlike the sunny second-floor apartment in the advertisement — I resigned myself to a thrice-weekly Amtrak commute. Those four hours on the train each day have afforded lots of opportunities for out-the-window gazing. When I sit on the east side of the train, I get to watch the rising sun shimmer on the Susquehanna River estuary, the Bush River, the Gunpowder River, and the Back River. From the western seats, I always try to catch a glimpse of Baltimore’s handsome Hoen & Co. Lithograph Complex, and I’ve enjoyed learning about its history and restoration.

 

Inside the Library’s 1897 Beaux Arts Jefferson Building, too, I’m struck by the infinite regress of architectural frames: the windows of all shapes and sizes, the nested coffers and moldings. Even the Kluge Center is an assemblage of rooms within a room: 13 offices and 26 carrels contained within a wooden gallery that runs the length of a sprawling hall. The windows of my office look out onto a perimeter walkway bordered by exterior windows. It feels a bit like inhabiting a Piranesi etching.

I contrast the Jefferson building’s copiously, ornately fenestrated space with that of DeWitt, Poor & Shelton’s 1980 Madison building, a ginormous, modernist box I’ve likened to Lumon Industries’ headquarters in Severance, a tv show that’s actually filmed (in part) at Eero Saarinen’s Bell Labs in Holmdel, New Jersey.

I’m particularly intrigued by the many windowless doors to the Congressional Research Service, which, as its name implies, does commissioned, confidential research — on law, environmental and social policy,  health care, housing, foreign affairs, science and industry, and related topics — for members of Congress and Congressional staff. The service’s 2023 annual report reflects significant interest in artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, and infrastructure security. Searching for research pertaining to media and libraries, I noted reports on drug trafficking on social media, social media content moderation, and big tech and antitrust. The only research relevant to libraries seemed to be a Federal Law Update on “curriculum laws and book removals.” I’ve visited the various research centers in the Madison building: the Geography & Map Reading Room; the Moving Image Research Center; the Newspaper & Current Periodical Reading Room; the Performing Arts Reading Room; the Recorded Sound Research Center; the Prints & Photographs Collection, with its plentiful card catalogs and filing cabinets stuffed with Farm Security Administration / Office of War Information photographs (1935-44). I plan to return to many of these collections in the coming months.

Yet most of my time thus far has been spent in the windowless Manuscripts Reading Room, engaging with the papers of designers Charles and Ray Eames. For nearly two decades I’ve been mortise-and-tenoning together a research agenda on “case logics” or “intellectual furnishings” — that is: how furniture design shapes our thought and scaffolds our intellectual labor. I’ve written pieces about Louis Kahn’s book carrels and Alvar Aalto’s hexagonal listening stations, bookshelves and closets, the big, collaborative work tables in Silicon Valley tech companies and the tiny tables at Justice Kavanaugh’s confirmation hearing, the relationships between 19th-century secret drawers and cybersecurity; and those between architectural containers and memory loss, the ethics and aesthetics of Shaker architectures and furniture of containment, and the furniture supporting pandemic home-based labor.

During my fellowship period and in the months that follow, I plan to expand on this research — both in the archives and in the woodshop: the LoC’s carpentry shop, the shops of various furniture makers along my routes of travel, and my dad’s shop. Dad’s a highly skilled furniture maker who’s faced a great deal of heartache and loss over the past several years. The challenges of my own job, with its significant service demands and institutional crises, have repeatedly thwarted my attempts to apprentice with him — but the recent destruction of dad’s shop and wood storage barn in a fire has rekindled my conviction both to help him rebuild (a new shop full of windows!) and to celebrate his work through my own. I want my work in words and pictures to be a window onto his work in wood.

As is the case in most libraries and archives with limited space, a great deal of the Library of Congress’s collection is stored off-site. Thus, the windowless reading rooms — and even the Library’s catalog — are themselves merely small windows onto the vast holdings of this institution, the largest library in the world. I had to wait a couple days for Eames Series I to be delivered from somewhere off-site. Within the collection I then found myriad windows onto the Eameses’s projects, processes, values, friendships (especially to Alexander and Susan Girard); onto the continual sexist diminishment of Ray’s contributions to their collective work; onto the couple’s commitment to making technology intelligible and convivial. I also found documentation of an exhibition, spanning nine windows at IBM’s 590 Madison Ave building, that documented the history of data processing.

When I’m working in the archives, sensorially enthralled with the material before me yet visually disengaged from the outside world, it’s easy to forget just how messy things are out there. And while Washington D.C.’s mall was designed to allow for grand views of regal public institutions and stirring monuments, the Library’s position across First St SE from the Capitol building, and severed from the Mall by that huge legislative complex, delimits its viewshed.

Yet when I head back to the Jefferson Building and walk up to the second floor of the Grand Hall, I can look out the west-facing windows toward the Capitol and the vast expanse of the United States beyond it. The other night, as Trump signed another wave of executive orders — right before an airplane and a helicopter plunged into the Potomac River, and the president suggested that the tragedy might be a consequence of diversity and equity initiatives — I watched the sun set on the Capitol and was almost nauseated by the simultaneous triteness and aptness of the metaphor.

I thought about the contrast between the epistemological values enshrined and operationalized in the Library‘s windows — both literal and metaphorical — and in the windows on Capitol Hill and in the White House hidden behind the Capitol’s dome. Here: the volumes and manuscripts and films and photographs behind and beneath me embody historical wisdom extending back millennia, afford a sense of accountability extending forward for millennia, and encompass the vast range of human and non-human experience. Over there, meanwhile, despotic decrees — lifted from Project 2025, gussied up in leather folios, and gilded with flamboyant Sharpie script — evidence a cognitive window limited to immediate personal profit, shaped by crypto-speculation, white supremacy, and xenophobia — all of which preclude the capacity to heed lessons from the past, or engender commitment to a fabricated and weaponized past). This window is a periscope, not a panorama or a palimpsest.

Meanwhile, in various government agencies around town, a team of unelected technocrats has been hoovering up personally-identifying information; erasing government data that acknowledges inconvenient facts; and shuttering the websites of agencies that “need to die.” Instant link-rot, internal cyber-sabotage: precisely the kind of digital devastation the Library’s digital preservation teams work hard to preclude. The purported “Department of Government Efficiency” has replaced the esteemed U.S. Digital Service, a team of gifted technologists committed to public service: building tools that facilitate democratic processes, creating interfaces — windows — to data and services that make government more effective, efficient (as in: accessible and operational), and transparent. This new regime defines “efficiency” quite differently: through the lenses of austerity, automation, and extraction. Eliminate what doesn’t make a profit, what makes you uncomfortable, what enables the survival of people and programs and concepts that “need to die.”

Through what windows will we imagine our future as a nation and a global society? Through stained glass and indigenous maps and flickering film screens and illuminated manuscripts and crystalline vitrines displaying cultural artifacts that embody a common, though still necessarily contested, human heritage? Through the interfaces of LLMs that supplant the labor and expertise of experienced and dedicated civil servants and educators and social workers? Through cryptocurrency dashboards? Through cockpits on spaceships to Mars — from which we can reflect back on the planet we’ve exhausted?

Goodbye, Ebullient Ellie https://wordsinspace.net/2025/01/26/48597/ Sun, 26 Jan 2025 04:24:53 +0000 Blog,dogs Today we said goodbye to another four-legged friend. We couldn’t allow him to suffer, so we gave him rest after nine ebullient years. Elliott joins Lily, Pippi, Dugan, Roxy, Rudy, Dexter, and Opie, […]

Today we said goodbye to another four-legged friend. Elliott succumbed to lung cancer that manifested very quickly and, over the course of two weeks, stole his appetite and his breath. We couldn’t allow him to suffer, so we gave him rest after nine ebullient years.

Elliott joins Lily, Pippi, Dugan, Roxy, Rudy, Dexter, and Opie, who preceded him into the hereafter, and who, I’m sure, have greeted him there. Ellie’s departure also comes at the end of a long period of loss: my dad, his primary caretaker, had, over the preceding three years alone, lost another beloved canine companion, made the difficult decision to place my mom in memory care, lost four very close friends, and, just three months ago, lost his woodshop and wood storage barn to fire. Ellie was a source of perpetual joy and unfailing friendship through all the turmoil — he’d continually nudge us with his nose to let us know he was there — so his departure weighs especially heavily.

Ellie and his brother, Duncan, who survives him, were born near Youngstown, OH, on November 18, 2015. Their border collie predecessor, Dugan, had recently passed away — on this very same day in 2016 — so my dad and brother drove west to pick up the classic white-and-black puppy they found online. When they arrived, they found that the-little-guy-who-would-become-Duncan (above, left) and the runt of the litter — a pup whose almost-all-black coloring made him relatively undesirable for snooty breed purists — were the only two remaining in the litter. Not wanting to separate the two or to leave anyone behind, dad and Nath decided to take both pups — Duncan and Elliott — back with them to Central PA, where they joined Lily at home. The three bonded quickly.Ellie liked to hug. These gestures of affection were not reserved for family members; they signaled welcome, too, to FedEx drivers and HVAC technicians and veterinarians. Ellie also expected reciprocal attention — and he regularly used his nose as a crowbar to pry his head into our laps or under our hands, to remind of us of our obligation to give pets.

More than anything, though, Ellie loved to run. My dad, who spent more time with him than anyone, says he was the most athletic of all of our border collies. From the moment he leaped out of bed, to the last bathroom break before sleep, Ellie was eager for a few long-distance frisbee tosses or laps around the yard. When Duncan decided to join the fetch session, they took turns — a lovely brotherly rhythm.

Ellie is such a force — manic joie de vivre incarnate! — and his absence is palpable, particularly to his twin brother. We’ll continue to find joy and fun and friendship amidst these dark times in his honor. We’ll love you forever, Ellie; we’re so grateful you shared your all-too-short life with us and gave us the honor of caring for you; and we’ll see you again, good boy.

Postcards from Palestine https://wordsinspace.net/2025/01/18/postcards-from-palestine/ Sat, 18 Jan 2025 08:29:04 +0000 Blog,Uncategorized,postcards,protest,textual form On Thursday the Evergreen Review shared a short story by Beirut-born Palestinian writer Mazen Maarouf about the speculative logistics of a postcard. During his first visit to Gaza, Mazen sought to send his father a Polaroid picture of the land where the family home once stood — but from which his father had been barred […]

On Thursday the Evergreen Review shared a short story by Beirut-born Palestinian writer Mazen Maarouf about the speculative logistics of a postcard. During his first visit to Gaza, Mazen sought to send his father a Polaroid picture of the land where the family home once stood — but from which his father had been barred since his exile. Unable to send the card through the post, Mazen serendipitously encountered a woman, Naima, who promised to hand-deliver the card — yet he later learned that she’s a notoriously unreliable messenger. Assuming the card had been lost, Mazen was surprised to hear, three weeks later, that his father had received the postcard — mere days before suffering a stroke. Yet when Mazen returned to Beirut, he found that his convalescing father possessed neither the card nor memory of its existence.

Years later, Mazen and his father spot Naima on television, which prompts his father to recollect a vivid dream: this same woman had visited him and delivered a postcard — Mazen’s postcard — depicting his Gazan homeland (Mazen’s mystery echoes that in Anne Berest’s The Postcard). On TV, Naima is gathering letters from school children, one of whom proclaims: "We’re writing letters to the world; envelopes is all that we found in the food storage facility. We write letters so we forget how hungry we are. Naima will deliver them. She sees addresses in her dreams. She knows by heart all the addresses in the world." The next day, the school is bombed, and Naima and the envelopes disappear with it. “The only meaningful thing I could do at that moment,” Mazen writes, “was to go down and check my mailbox.”

Like Naima, Palestinian-American artist Emily Jacir serves as both a vessel of hope and a human link within a broken infrastructure — a conduit for messages that connect severed lives (Lydia Pyne, in her history of postcards, also emphasizes their material role in connecting social networks). For her 2001-3 Where We Come From project, Jacir asked Palestinian exiles: “If I could do anything for you, anywhere in Palestine, what would it be?” “Taking advantage of her ability to move about relatively freely in Israel with an American passport,” T. J. Demos explains, “Jacir promised to realize the desires of those forbidden entry into their homeland.” Her execution of those promises — placing flowers on a mother’s grave, visiting a restaurant, playing soccer — manifests in an installation: black texts, in both Arabic and English, on white panels, documenting contributors’ requests; alongside color photographs verifying Jacir’s fulfillment of those requests.

Jacir’s paired texts and photos could be read as the opposing faces of a postcard, with the image capturing an aspirational (if often heartbreakingly mundane) site and experience, and the text offering a personalized message. Yet here the text — which exemplifies Barthes’ punctum, the subjectively poignant element that pricks and bruises — precedes and precipitates the photo. And what is so puncturing about those photos is the contrast between the depicted scenes’ banality for Jacir and their utter impossibility for the texts’ authors. (The anticipatory, instigating text is again present in Jacir’s letter to a friend, an epistolary film in which Jacir gathers evidence of the impending occupation of her family home in Bethlehem and asks a friend, the architect Eyal Weizman, to begin a preemptive investigation.)

The recognition of Palestinians’ sovereignty depends so much on the ontology of rhetorical forms: the map, the letter, the archival record, ID cards and passports, the ceasefire “deal,” the mandate, the declaration, the treaty, the small, light postcard that embodies a promise of mobility so many Palestinian people themselves do not possess. And as Maafour and Jacir show, those material media forms, as well as the people who carry them, often constitute an informal infrastructure in their own right, particularly when, as Helga Tawil-Souri demonstrates, “official” infrastructures are unreliable, obstructionist, surveillant, extractive, or deadly.

Nadine Fattaleh, a Palestinian writer and translator from Amman, acknowledges the infrastructures of censorship — implemented by everyone from state governments to social media platforms to university administrations — that exist to impede Palestine solidarity protest and the circulation of protest images. Last year, New York University, where Fattaleh is a PhD student (and where I, coincidentally, earned my PhD, too), was particularly draconian, barricading public spaces, arresting protesting students and faculty, disciplining those students by requiring them to complete an “Ethos Integrity” training and write a reflection paper, banning journalism faculty documenting peaceful protests, issuing year-long suspensions to students involved in sit-ins, and establishing restrictive conduct and speech policies that deem Zionists a protected class. Again we see an authority delimiting the recognition of Palestinian sovereignty by controlling the rhetorical forms in which, and the infrastructures through which, political speech can transpire.

Fatalleh suggests that, amidst these impediments, “the medium of print has returned to combat repression, with the increased production of posters, flyers, zines, and pamphlets circulated at demonstrations, community gatherings, and university encampments.” And at NYU’s Asian/Pacific/American Institute last fall, she created a “living archive” of these print materials for her Materials of Solidarity exhibition, which, she noted, “echoes the movement’s insistence: ‘the more they try to silence us, the louder we will be.'” Here, that amplification is effected not sonically, but through graphic vibrancy, material accumulation and distribution, and affective engagement.

Immediately inside the gallery door and to the left one finds a sample of materials from the People’s Library at the Palestine solidarity encampments, as well as a selection of zines from Fattaleh’s own collection. I’ve included a few above; Fattaleh made sure to draw my attention to the lovely box set of maps, A1 Block Walker’s Log. On the opposite wall we encounter wall text and rows of orange envelopes featuring, on one side, a photograph depicting a keffiyeh-wrapped protester and an assortment of hand-lettered protest posters, and, on the other side, the curatorial statement in compressed form. These envelopes structure our engagement with the work situated deeper into the gallery.

On the perpendicular wall — what we see directly in front of us upon entry — are three sets of shelves, each with four rows, collectively featuring stacks of ~80 postcards: “The collectively assembled postcards, paired with documentation of the intimate reflections of anonymous contributors, are a palimpsest of our community and its protest of the ongoing, mediatized genocide of the Palestinian people in Gaza,” Fattaleh says. These texts, personalized captions for the images on the cards’ flip side, are punctums, too. We’re to gather and store a selection of these cards in our orange envelopes.

The postcards depict protest media in myriad formats: photos of students reading texts about Palestinian history, diagrams outlining the role of Israeli technology in entrenching apartheid, mixed-media collages of Palestinians killed under occupation, cut-up poetry about the prevailing solidarity amidst institutional violence at the encampments, a photo of assorted cardboard protest signs, depictions of the NYPD’s tools of sonic warfare, a photo of annotated and defaced copies of university policies, a photo of solidarity banners hung from the atrium screen in NYU’s Bobst Library.

Fattaleh writes, “The exhibition accumulates images born of the history and reality of Palestinian struggle, and their recombinant mutation across spaces, generations and possibilities of solidarity and resistance. It offers reproductions of postcards as materials of solidarity that must proliferate into the world. From our campus and workplace, to streets and open spaces, let our images and words multiply, distributing the collective energy of protest against genocide and reverberating the refusal of our collective complicity.” (Similarly, Annelies Moors writes about Macha Saca’s post-intifada postcards depicting the diversity of Palestinian dress; those cards, through their circulation, were meant both to encourage Palestinians to be “aware of and appreciate their own cultural heritage,” and to inform foreigners about that heritage “in order to be convinced of the historical presence and national rights of the Palestinian people.”)

In late November I attended a gallery tour, after which I asked Fattaleh to say a bit more about the postcard as her chosen medium — and about what it means to share these postcards within a gallery on the third floor of an access-restricted university building that visitors must register, at least a day in advance, to enter. She explained that those of us who gather in the gallery — an inclusive space of exception on campus — can then spread its messages throughout the city. We are its social broadcast network, its circulation infrastructure. I imagined the postcards as the watermelon seeds depicted throughout the exhibition, and us, the exhibition visitors, as the pollinators who distribute them.

 

“Images are progenitors of another possible world,” Fattaleh writes. And images on postcards — a medium defined by its brevity and exposure; a medium that, as Jennifer Croft describes it, is “hardy and delicate at once, dated and timeless, telltale and intimate, representative and not”; a medium both “semi-intimate and semi-public” — are sent out into the world-as-it-is, to invite their recipients to hold in their hands a microcosmic prototype of worlds-to-be. Long deployed as commercial advertisements, or as emblems of “colonialist exoticism and political propaganda,” postcards can also create a different topology and phenomenology of protest and political education: one that transpires through intimate, individual engagements and a literal holding of possibilities, while also signaling the potential for incremental, global circulation and propagation.

Ellsworth Kelly, like many artists before him, appreciated the postcard’s material affordances and limitations. He worked at the Farley post office! As Rebecca Bengal explains, “For Kelly, postcards were a vacation from the studio. They were both outlet and outline, made quickly and intuitively: Some were places to work out ideas, and a few loose compositions would lead in more obvious ways to larger, more fully realized pieces. Others were just to escape, to play and have fun.”

Maarouf’s and Jacir’s and Fattaleh’s collaborators’ postcards encapsulate dreams and laments. In their very form they embody an easy mobility both impossible and aspirational; the images and messages they carry are means of “working out ideas.” In their accumulation and abundant circulation, perhaps these postcards, then, can plant seeds and model speculative infrastructures for worlds to come.
